description.p: Specifies where to place the node on the map. Coordinates are in pixel units, with the origin at the top-left of the map.

Optionally, you can also specify another node that the coordinates are relative to. This allows you to have 'sub-nodes' that follow a master node around as you alter the map. Relative nodes can be relative to other relative nodes, as long as the node at the end of the chain is not relatively positioned!
You can also specify a relative position to another node in polar coordinates, with an angle (in degrees) and a distance. This can make it simpler to arrange child nodes in a circle around a parent.

Finally, you can also position a node relative to another using named offsets. These are defined in the parent node (or a template node it uses) using the DEFINEOFFSET command. This can be useful for things like switch ports - a single node can have offsets defined for each port in a large icon of the switch, and then smaller per-port status icons can be specified to overlay 'switch1:p1'.

example.caption: Example of a 'sub-node', that will be 20 pixels above the main node, wherever that gets moved to. It is used to show additional information about the main node.
example.content:
NODE main_node POSITION 200 320 LABEL MAIN
NODE sub_node POSITION main_node 0 -20 LABEL {nodes:main_node:invalue}

changes.change: Add relative position from other nodes.
